<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TAX
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/08/nearly-140-countries-agree-to-updated-global-tax-framework?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Doing the Maximum to Get the Minimum
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/08/nearly-140-countries-agree-to-updated-global-tax-framework?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt='Clovers spelling out "15%"' style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/2c0c3bc541e01ea5736d2f883daf71e2d7532953-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba </em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After years of bruising negotiations, 136 countries agreed yesterday to establish a <a href="https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/what-is-global-minimum-tax-deal-what-will-it-mean-2021-10-08/?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">global corporate minimum tax</a> of 15% and laid out other measures that will help them scoop up more tax revenue from large, multinational corporations.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>How much revenue? As much as $150 billion annually, according to the Organization for Cooperation and Economic Development (OECD).</span></li></ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">How a minimum tax works</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you establish a tax floor, it prevents countries from perpetually <a href="https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/what-is-global-minimum-tax-deal-what-will-it-mean-2021-10-08/?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">lowering their tax rates</a> to make themselves more attractive to globe-trotting corporations looking for a new, cheaper home. In economic circles, this is called the “race to the bottom.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Exhibit A: </strong>Ireland. In 2003, Ireland lowered its corporate tax rate to a measly 12.5%, and soon after welcomed a wave of multinationals looking to lower their tax bills. The largest US tech firms, including Facebook, Google, and Apple, have all set up their European headquarters in the country.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Because of its success with a low tax rate, Ireland was one of the key holdouts of the minimum tax plan, but it finally <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/07/ireland-agrees-to-be-a-part-of-global-minimum-tax-agreement?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">came on board</a> Thursday in the name of cooperation.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Important note: </strong>The minimum tax is just one pillar of the new global tax framework. Another will allow countries to tax large companies that sell goods or services in their jurisdictions but don’t have a physical footprint—an acknowledgment of how digital commerce has transformed the global economy.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">So what’s next?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Countries agreeing with each other was the easy part. Now, they'll have to sell the plan to their own legislatures. That could be tough, especially in the US, a country that is crucial to any global tax agreement but also home to fierce disagreements between its only two major political parties.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">An aggressive date has been set for the updated global tax scheme to take effect: 2023.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/08/underwhelming-september-jobs-report-highlights-low-impact-benefits-have-on-labor-market?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
September Jobs Report in a GIF
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/08/underwhelming-september-jobs-report-highlights-low-impact-benefits-have-on-labor-market?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Guy failing to dunk a basketball" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/5d96536e4bd235fdf1bf9277b99b97e99660c48b-480x322.gif?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The September jobs report was about as underwhelming as a Secret Santa gift. The US economy added 194,000 jobs in September, well below expectations of 500,000. It’s the <a href="https://www.npr.org/2021/10/08/1044137160/no-it-hasnt-been-the-job-recovery-many-had-expected-but-theres-room-for-hope?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">weakest job growth</a> of any month in 2021.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><strong style="color:#000">There’s a twist:</strong></span><span> The unemployment rate dropped to 4.8% from 5.2% in August.</span>
</li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Don’t stress if you’re confused—so are experts. They thought that a record number of open positions +  a recovering economy would lead to a surge in job growth in the back half of the year. But the persistent challenge of finding workers and the Delta variant has made hiring an uphill battle.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A few other nuggets from the report:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><strong style="color:#000">Women are leaving the job market.</strong></span><span> Experts believed that schools reopening in-person would take some of the childcare burden off moms and allow them to get back to work. However, September saw the </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-08/women-leaving-u-s-workforce-drive-participation-rate-drop?srnd=premium" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">lowest number</a></span><span> of women employed or looking for a job since February.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><strong style="color:#000">Removing enhanced UI benefits was not a panacea. </strong></span><span>Enhanced federal unemployment benefits expired nationwide on Labor Day. But, confirming previous research, taking away the extra payments appeared to </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/08/september-jobs-report-covid-pandemic-unemployment-benefits.html?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">do little</a></span><span> to boost employment.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>What’s holding back the job market right now is the significant number of Americans <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/08/upshot/jobs-report-september.html?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">not looking for work at all</a>, according to the NYT.—<em>MM</em></p>
</div>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MARKETING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/08/google-bans-ads-that-deny-climate-change?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
An Inconvenient Policy for Climate Deniers
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Climate change deniers are <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2021/10/7/22715102/google-youtube-climate-change-deniers-ads-monetization?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">no longer allowed</a> to make money from their beliefs on Google and YouTube, according to a new policy the tech giant posted Thursday.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That means on YouTube no ads will display on content that contradicts the existence of climate change, deny that human activity has contributed to it, or generally disappoint Bill Nye. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Google wrote that advertisers have been </span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/article/climate-change-technology-business-misinformation-environment-and-nature-6de418655b159e55311cc81c9efe17df?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">specifically asking</a></span><span> for a crackdown on climate-denying content because they “simply don’t want their ads to appear next to” it. Which...fair.</span>
</li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> The move to strip climate deniers from monetizing their content is the latest volley in Google’s attempt to rein in misinformation. Just last week, YouTube banned all content that makes speculative or downright false claims about approved vaccines.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The policy’s also part of a recent push from Google to highlight environmental issues. On Wednesday, Google Flights rolled out <a href="https://www.npr.org/2021/10/06/1043803529/google-flights-carbon-emissions-air-travel?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">a feature</a> that lets you see how carbon-friendly your flight is, on a scale of Greta Thunberg → flamethrower-equipped monster truck.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we’re here: </strong>Climate change is a hot topic (whoops) in the advertising world right now. Fossil-fuel clients are becoming a “reputational risk,” Marketing Brew’s <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/marketing/stories/2021/10/08/a-group-of-creatives-is-pressuring-agencies-to-give-up-fossil-fuel-clients?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ryan Barwick reports</a>.—<em>JW</em></p>
</div>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Erik McGregor/LightRocket via Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>With an estimated $10 trillion in assets under management, the investment giant BlackRock is <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/7dfd1e3d-e256-4656-a96d-1204538d75cd?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">as big as</a> the global hedge fund, private equity, and venture capital industries combined.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“It was a nice break from everything.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Livae Nanjikana was feeling refreshed after he and another man from the Solomon Islands spent 29 days <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/oct/08/it-was-a-nice-break-from-everything-two-men-rescued-after-29-days-lost-at-sea?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=mb" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">lost at sea</a>. You know the world’s going through a rough patch when being stranded by a storm off the coast of Papua New Guinea sounds like a yoga retreat in Joshua Tree.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>What I learned about my writing by seeing just the punctuation. style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nDoing the Maximum to Get the Minimum\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/08/nearly-140-countries-agree-to-updated-global-tax-framework?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" style=\"text-decoration:none;border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt='Clovers spelling out \"15%\"' style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/2c0c3bc541e01ea5736d2f883daf71e2d7532953-1500x1000.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAfter years of bruising negotiations, 136 countries agreed yesterday to establish a \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/what-is-global-minimum-tax-deal-what-will-it-mean-2021-10-08/?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eglobal corporate minimum tax\u003c/a\u003e of 15% and laid out other measures that will help them scoop up more tax revenue from large, multinational corporations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHow much revenue? As much as $150 billion annually, according to the Organization for Cooperation and Economic Development (OECD).\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eHow a minimum tax works\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you establish a tax floor, it prevents countries from perpetually \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/what-is-global-minimum-tax-deal-what-will-it-mean-2021-10-08/?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elowering their tax rates\u003c/a\u003e to make themselves more attractive to globe-trotting corporations looking for a new, cheaper home. In economic circles, this is called the “race to the bottom.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eExhibit A: \u003c/strong\u003eIreland. In 2003, Ireland lowered its corporate tax rate to a measly 12.5%, and soon after welcomed a wave of multinationals looking to lower their tax bills. The largest US tech firms, including Facebook, Google, and Apple, have all set up their European headquarters in the country.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBecause of its success with a low tax rate, Ireland was one of the key holdouts of the minimum tax plan, but it finally \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/07/ireland-agrees-to-be-a-part-of-global-minimum-tax-agreement?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecame on board\u003c/a\u003e Thursday in the name of cooperation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eImportant note: \u003c/strong\u003eThe minimum tax is just one pillar of the new global tax framework. Another will allow countries to tax large companies that sell goods or services in their jurisdictions but don’t have a physical footprint—an acknowledgment of how digital commerce has transformed the global economy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eSo what’s next?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCountries agreeing with each other was the easy part. Now, they'll have to sell the plan to their own legislatures. That could be tough, especially in the US, a country that is crucial to any global tax agreement but also home to fierce disagreements between its only two major political parties.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAn aggressive date has been set for the updated global tax scheme to take effect: 2023.—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe September jobs report was about as underwhelming as a Secret Santa gift. The US economy added 194,000 jobs in September, well below expectations of 500,000. It’s the \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/2021/10/08/1044137160/no-it-hasnt-been-the-job-recovery-many-had-expected-but-theres-room-for-hope?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eweakest job growth\u003c/a\u003e of any month in 2021.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThere’s a twist:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e The unemployment rate dropped to 4.8% from 5.2% in August.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eDon’t stress if you’re confused—so are experts. They thought that a record number of open positions +  a recovering economy would lead to a surge in job growth in the back half of the year. But the persistent challenge of finding workers and the Delta variant has made hiring an uphill battle.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eA few other nuggets from the report:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWomen are leaving the job market.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Experts believed that schools reopening in-person would take some of the childcare burden off moms and allow them to get back to work. However, September saw the \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-08/women-leaving-u-s-workforce-drive-participation-rate-drop?srnd=premium\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elowest number\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e of women employed or looking for a job since February.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eRemoving enhanced UI benefits was not a panacea. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eEnhanced federal unemployment benefits expired nationwide on Labor Day. But, confirming previous research, taking away the extra payments appeared to \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/08/september-jobs-report-covid-pandemic-unemployment-benefits.html?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=mb\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edo little\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e to boost employment.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eWhat’s holding back the job market right now is the significant number of Americans \u003ca style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enot looking for work at all\u003c/a\u003e, according to the class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003especifically asking\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e for a crackdown on Just last week, YouTube banned all content that makes speculative or downright false claims about approved vaccines.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe policy’s also part of a recent push from Google to highlight environmental issues.
